title: New North Church, Edinburgh
author: Livingston, Josiah.
snippet: Some arrangement had been made when the alteration on St Giles' was fixed on whereby a new church was to be built for Mr Bruce, and for this purpose, while we were in the Methodist Chapel, there was a grand ceremonial laying the foundation on the Castlehill; but, failing Mr Bruce, the new church and our old parish were to go to the congregation of the Tolbooth Church, and a new parish was to be cut out for the New North, which wag afterwards fixed to be in the High Street, between St Giles' and the Tron Church on the north, and the Cowgate on the south. But when Mr Bruce left us not a stone had been built of our new church now called the Assembly Hall, and the congregation was told just to remain where it was in Brighton Street. Our parish was taken from us by the Tolbooth people, while the new one was not fixed for us for some time, so in addition to wanting minister, precentor, bedrell, and great part of the congregation, we were minus a parish also.

title: New North Church, Edinburgh
author: Livingston, Josiah.
snippet: When we thought we had trespassed long enough on the hospitality of our Congregationalist friends, in November 1843 we resumed possession of our old meeting-house in Brighton Street, the residuary congregation having been transferred to West St Giles'. We continued there till the church was sold over our heads, and we found refuge in Dr Ritchie's church in the Potterrow in 1846, and were there till our new church in Forrest Road was opened in June 1848.

title: New North Church, Edinburgh
author: Livingston, Josiah.
snippet: But there came an entire change over the New North. The Town Council had discovered that the rent paid for the Methodist Chapel was too high, and they hired for us a big cold chapel in Brighton Street, which was empty at the time. To this we shifted in 1836, and we did not like the change.

title: New North Church, Edinburgh
author: Livingston, Josiah.
snippet: The draft is in the handwriting of the young man whom Mr Livingston allowed to assist him, and was adopted without one word of alteration. When the time of action came, and we had to leave the Establishment in May 1843, we went almost as a congregation, leaving the church in Brighton Street. We were hospitably entertained by the Independent Congregation in Argyle Square, the minister of which, Dr Alexander, and his people generously altering their hours of worship so as to share the day with us.

title: New North Church, Edinburgh
author: Livingston, Josiah.
snippet: by the Disruption, and the excitement from it and this subsequent work told on his nervous system, so that he became seriously ill in the September of 1844, and continued unfit for service till November 1845. We were worshipping in Brighton Street, when he preached his first sermon after his restoration from the text, "Thanks be unto God for His unspeakable gift." During his illness we received most willing and much appreciated help from many of the best ministers of the church, which leads me to speak of the kind of assistance which Mr Brown drew to himself and his people.
